title: Hong Kong murder suspect Chan Tong-kai’s transfer to Taiwan should be delayed until after island’s presidential election, lawmaker says
text:
A pro-establishment barrister and lawmaker has proposed postponing the voluntary surrender of a Hong Kong murder suspect to Taiwan by three months until after the island’s presidential election, as the two sides wrangle over the case which sparked the city’s current political crisis.

Priscilla Leung Mei-fun, also a Basic Law Committee member, said that would protect the suspect, Chan Tong-kai, from being used in political bargains.

After spending 19 months in custody on money-laundering charges, Chan, wanted for the murder of his pregnant girlfriend in Taiwan, walked out of Pik Uk Correctional Institution in Clear Water Bay, Hong Kong, on Wednesday.

His case ignited the city’s extradition bill crisis after Chief Executive Carrie Lam Cheng Yuet-ngor proposed a bill in February, now withdrawn, to allow fugitive transfers to jurisdictions the city does not have an extradition agreement with, including mainland China and Taiwan.

On Wednesday all eyes were on whether the 20-year-old student would board a plane to Taiwan soon after his release.

Reverend Canon Peter Koon Ho-ming, the city’s top Anglican priest, who played a key role in persuading Chan to surrender to Taiwan authorities, said it was unlikely the student would leave Hong Kong on Thursday.

Speaking on a radio programme on Thursday, Leung said she was worried Chan would not be treated fairly.

“Since Chan has already agreed to surrender, I do not see a need to rush,” Leung said. “Chan can actually wait until the presidential election in Taiwan is done in January, so that he would not become a chip for political bargaining.”

She accused the Taiwanese authorities of prejudice in the case.

“From what the Taiwan government has said, it seems they already assumed Chan had planned to murder his girlfriend in Hong Kong, before the case goes to court. Whether the suspect planned the killing or it was just impulsive could bring a totally different result in jail terms. I am worried that the trial would be unfair,” Leung said.

Taiwan had reversed its earlier stance of not accepting Chan from Hong Kong on Tuesday, but stipulated he should be escorted back to the self-ruled island by Taiwanese police and prosecutors, who would be sent to the city to pick him up.

Taiwan has been changing its way of speaking every day. Let us give them some time to clear things up first

Lawmaker Priscilla Leung

The Hong Kong government slammed the offer as “disrespect” for the city’s jurisdictional power and “totally unacceptable”.

Leung, however, said it could be feasible for Taiwan police to “just stay on the Taiwan plane inside a Hong Kong restricted area and wait for Chan to get on board on his own”.

“There are a lot of options worldwide. A suspect can be surrendered as long as it is voluntary. But it has to be based on mutual respect,” she said. “Taiwan has been changing its way of speaking every day. Let us give them some time to clear things up first.”

Legal academic Eric Cheung Tat-ming, of the University of Hong Kong, said there was nothing wrong with Taiwan having political considerations. But, he added, it would be totally unacceptable for its authorities to enforce law in Hong Kong.

Priscilla Leung accused the Taiwanese authorities of prejudice in the Chan Tong-kai case. Photo: Nora Tam More

Cheung said the only way to ensure a fair trial was a simple legal amendment on jurisdiction outside Hong Kong, so the suspect could stand trial in the city.

His remarks came after Secretary for Justice Teresa Cheng Yeuk-wah rejected a claim by Chiu Chui-cheng, vice-chairman of Taiwan’s Mainland Affairs Council, that Hong Kong had given up all jurisdiction over the murder. Cheng said Hong Kong simply followed a legal principle restricting its courts to dealing with offences which took place within its territory.
